questions.question_text_1: Four teams (1, 2, 3 and 4) have qualified for the final of the cricket world cup. Team 1 plays Team 2. Team 3 plays Team 4. The winners then play for final. In a game between Team “i” and Team “j”, the probability of team “i” winning is given by {i /(i+j)}. Then what is the conditional probability that “Team 1” will win the World Cup? (Note: Enter your answer in decimals rounded to two decimal places. For example, if your answer is “0.245”, enter it as “0.25”)
question_texts: Four teams (1, 2, 3 and 4) have qualified for the final of the cricket world cup. Team 1 plays Team 2. Team 3 plays Team 4. The winners then play for final. In a game between Team “i” and Team “j”, the probability of team “i” winning is given by {i /(i+j)}. Then what is the conditional probability that “Team 1” will win the World Cup? (Note: Enter your answer in decimals rounded to two decimal places. For example, if your answer is “0.245”, enter it as “0.25”)

questions.question_text_1:
The monthly electric power consumed by the paint shop in an automobile assembly line is thought to be related to “Average ambient temperature (X1)”, “Number of working days in the month (X2)” and “Total surface area that is painted (X3)”. The past historical data (in Table-1) was used to build a model containing these variables and the developed regression model is provided below. 
Electric Power Consumed = 857.75+ 4.25*X1 – 40.75*X2 + 3.45*X3

questions.question_text_1: The BA discourse is often cluttered with queries / requests related to solutions for Past Year Question Papers (PYQP). The course instructor, Dr. Milo, had been informing that students need to put in effort to find solutions by searching the discourse. However, the results seem to disappointing. Therefore, Dr. Milo wanted to do a few basic analytics on discourse behaviour of students. Past student data was collected for the analysis. Past data was collected for the BA terms in Jan-2022, May-2022, Sep-2022, Jan-2023, May-2023 and Sep-2023. For each term, 100 randomly selected unique student IDs were sampled. Of the 100 student IDs, 50 were “Male” and the remaining were “Female”. The learners in the discourse have either “followed the instructions” or “not followed the instructions” or “have not accessed the discourse at all” (these three are referred to as access categories). Specifically, for the sample data in the different terms (in sequence of earliest term to latest term i.e. Jan-2022 to Sep-2023) it was observed that • For the Male sample: 20, 30, 25, 45, 25 and 35 had followed the instructions (respectively in each term i.e 20 male learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) • For the Male sample: 2, 10, 5, 4, 5 and 3 had not accessed discourse at all (respectively in each term i.e 2 male learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) • For the female sample: 15, 22, 32, 25, 20 and 20 had followed the instructions (respectively in each term i.e 15 female learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) and the remaining learners in the respective female sample had not followed the instructions Moreover, Dr. Milo assumes that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Normally distributed with a mean of 18 and standard deviation of 4. Each BA term is taken as a sample point to identify the required counts (for this specific analysis). A binning of data is performed with the following three bins (which capture the number of learners who follow the instructions in a sample). The bins divide the solution space into equal areas. Bin-1: [less than or equal to 35] Bin-2: [36 to less than or equal to 50] Bin-3: [51 to less than or equal to 100] Given this information, answer the subquestions

Bin-1: [less than or equal to 35] Bin-2: [36 to less than or equal to 50] Bin-3: [51 to less than or equal to 100] Given this information, answer the subquestions
question_texts: The BA discourse is often cluttered with queries / requests related to solutions for Past Year Question Papers (PYQP). The course instructor, Dr. Milo, had been informing that students need to put in effort to find solutions by searching the discourse. However, the results seem to disappointing. Therefore, Dr. Milo wanted to do a few basic analytics on discourse behaviour of students. Past student data was collected for the analysis. Past data was collected for the BA terms in Jan-2022, May-2022, Sep-2022, Jan-2023, May-2023 and Sep-2023. For each term, 100 randomly selected unique student IDs were sampled. Of the 100 student IDs, 50 were “Male” and the remaining were “Female”. The learners in the discourse have either “followed the instructions” or “not followed the instructions” or “have not accessed the discourse at all” (these three are referred to as access categories). Specifically, for the sample data in the different terms (in sequence of earliest term to latest term i.e. Jan-2022 to Sep-2023) it was observed that • For the Male sample: 20, 30, 25, 45, 25 and 35 had followed the instructions (respectively in each term i.e 20 male learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) • For the Male sample: 2, 10, 5, 4, 5 and 3 had not accessed discourse at all (respectively in each term i.e 2 male learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) • For the female sample: 15, 22, 32, 25, 20 and 20 had followed the instructions (respectively in each term i.e 15 female learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) and the remaining learners in the respective female sample had not followed the instructions Moreover, Dr. Milo assumes that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Normally distributed with a mean of 18 and standard deviation of 4. Each BA term is taken as a sample point to identify the required counts (for this specific analysis). A binning of data is performed with the following three bins (which capture the number of learners who follow the instructions in a sample). The bins divide the solution space into equal areas. Bin-1: [less than or equal to 35] Bin-2: [36 to less than or equal to 50] Bin-3: [51 to less than or equal to 100] Given this information, answer the subquestions

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **Diploma Level: Business Analytics (Computer-Based Exam)**. The summary is organized by topic, followed by a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships.

---

---

### **1. Probability & Conditional Probability**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Conditional Probability**: Probability of an event given another event has occurred.
  Formula:
  \[
  P(A|B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}
  \]
- **Independent Events**: Events where the occurrence of one does not affect the other.
- **Probability of Winning**: Given as \( \frac{i}{i+j} \) for Team \( i \) vs. Team \( j \).

#### **Example (Q2):**
- Calculate the probability of **Team 1 winning the World Cup** by considering all possible paths (Team 1 vs. Team 2 → Final) and their probabilities.

---

### **2. Linear Regression**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Regression Equation**:
  \[
  Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2 + \dots + \beta_n X_n + \epsilon
  \]
  (Example: \( \text{Electric Power} = 857.75 + 4.25X_1 - 40.75X_2 + 3.45X_3 \))
- **R-squared (\( R^2 \))**: Proportion of variance in the dependent variable explained by the model.
  Formula:
  \[
  R^2 = 1 - \frac{SS_{res}}{SS_{tot}}
  \]
- **Adjusted \( R^2 \)**: Adjusts for the number of predictors.
  Formula:
  \[
  \text{Adjusted } R^2 = 1 - \left( \frac{(1-R^2)(n-1)}{n-p-1} \right)
  \]
  where \( n \) = sample size, \( p \) = number of predictors.
- **Prediction**: Plug in values for \( X_1, X_2, \dots \) to estimate \( Y \).
- **Variance Inflation Factor (VIF)**: Measures multicollinearity.
  Formula:
  \[
  VIF_i = \frac{1}{1 - R_i^2}
  \]
  where \( R_i^2 \) is the \( R^2 \) of regressing \( X_i \) on all other predictors.

#### **Example (Q3-Q6):**
- Given a regression model, calculate:
  - \( R^2 \) and Adjusted \( R^2 \) from data.
  - Predicted \( Y \) for new \( X \) values.
  - VIF for \( X_1 \) and \( X_3 \) using correlation matrix.

---

### **3. Hypothesis Testing**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Chi-Square Test for Independence**:
  - Tests if categorical variables are independent.
  - Test statistic:
    \[
    \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_i - E_i)^2}{E_i}
    \]
    where \( O_i \) = observed frequency, \( E_i \) = expected frequency.
- **Goodness-of-Fit Test**:
  - Tests if data follows a distribution (e.g., normal).
  - Degrees of freedom = \( k - 1 - p \) (where \( k \) = bins, \( p \) = estimated parameters).

#### **Example (Q7-Q9):**
- Test if **male learners' access categories** are independent across terms (Chi-Square).
- Test if **followers of instructions** are normally distributed (Chi-Square Goodness-of-Fit).
- Degrees of freedom for the normality test.

---

### **4. Logistic Regression**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Confusion Matrix**: Evaluates classification performance.
  |               | Predicted Positive | Predicted Negative |
  |---------------|--------------------|--------------------|
  | Actual Positive| True Positive (TP)  | False Negative (FN)|
  | Actual Negative| False Positive (FP) | True Negative (TN) |
- **Metrics**:
  - **Accuracy**:
    \[
    \text{Accuracy} = \frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN}
    \]
  - **Recall (Sensitivity)**:
    \[
    \text{Recall} = \frac{TP}{TP + FN}
    \]
  - **Precision**:
    \[
    \text{Precision} = \frac{TP}{TP + FP}
    \]
  - **Specificity**:
    \[
    \text{Specificity} = \frac{TN}{TN + FP}
    \]
- **Logistic Regression Equation**:
  \[
  \log \left( \frac{p}{1-p} \right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2
  \]
  where \( p \) = probability of class 1.

#### **Example (Q10-Q11, Q24-Q28):**
- Calculate **accuracy, recall, precision, sensitivity, and specificity** from a confusion matrix.
- Use logistic regression coefficients to predict class probabilities.

---

### **5. Linear Programming (LP)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Standard Form**:
  - Maximize/Minimize \( c^T x \)
  - Subject to \( Ax \leq b \), \( x \geq 0 \).
- **Decision Variables**: Number of variables to optimize (e.g., manufacture vs. purchase).
- **Constraints**: Resource limits (e.g., time, budget).
- **Dual Problem**: Derived from the primal LP; variables in dual correspond to constraints in primal.
- **Objective Function**: Total cost or profit to optimize.

#### **Example (Q12-Q15):**
- Formulate an LP for **manufacturing vs. purchasing components** with constraints on time and cost.
- Calculate the **objective function value** and **dual variables**.

---

### **6. Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Efficiency Measurement**: Compares inputs/outputs of Decision-Making Units (DMUs).
- **DEA Model (CCR)**:
  - Maximize efficiency \( \theta \) for a DMU.
  - Constraints ensure no DMU exceeds 100% efficiency.
- **Objective Function**:
  \[
  \text{Maximize } \theta = \frac{\sum u_i y_i}{\sum v_j x_j}
  \]
  where \( u_i \) = output weights, \( v_j \) = input weights.
- **Reference Units**: Efficient DMUs used to benchmark inefficient ones.

#### **Example (Q16-Q23):**
- Formulate a **DEA LP** for a sales office.
- Identify **efficient DMUs** and **reference units** from a graph.
- Calculate **outputs for a DMU** given efficiency and reference units.

---

### **7. Conjoint Analysis**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Part-Worth Utilities**: Utility values for attribute levels.
- **Approaches**:
  - **Regression**: For metric data.
  - **Optimization**: For pairwise comparisons.
- **Ideal Product**: Closest to customer preferences (minimizes distance in attribute space).

#### **Example (Q29-Q31):**
- Choose the correct approach for **continuous pairwise data** (optimization).
- Interpret **customer preference** based on distances to ideal product.

---

---
### **Mermaid Knowledge Graph**
Below are the **Mermaid syntax graphs** to visualize relationships between topics.

#### **Graph 1: Core Topics Overview**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Business Analytics] --> B[Probability]
    A --> C[Regression]
    A --> D[Hypothesis Testing]
    A --> E[Logistic Regression]
    A --> F[Linear Programming]
    A --> G[DEA]
    A --> H[Conjoint Analysis]

    B --> B1[Conditional Probability]
    B --> B2[Independent Events]

    C --> C1[Linear Regression]
    C --> C2[R-squared]
    C --> C3[Adjusted R-squared]
    C --> C4[VIF]

    D --> D1[Chi-Square Test]
    D --> D2[Goodness-of-Fit]

    E --> E1[Confusion Matrix]
    E --> E2[Accuracy/Recall/Precision]

    F --> F1[Primal/Dual LP]
    F --> F2[Decision Variables]
    F --> F3[Constraints]

    G --> G1[Efficiency Measurement]
    G --> G2[Reference Units]

    H --> H1[Part-Worth Utilities]
    H --> H2[Optimization Approach]
```

#### **Graph 2: Regression & Hypothesis Testing**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Regression] --> B[Linear Regression]
    A --> C[Logistic Regression]

    B --> B1[Equation: Y = β0 + β1X1 + ...]
    B --> B2[R-squared]
    B --> B3[Adjusted R-squared]
    B --> B4[VIF]

    C --> C1[Confusion Matrix]
    C --> C2[Accuracy]
    C --> C3[Recall]
    C --> C4[Precision]

    D[Hypothesis Testing] --> D1[Chi-Square]
    D1 --> D1a[Independence]
    D1 --> D1b[Goodness-of-Fit]
```

#### **Graph 3: Linear Programming & DEA**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Linear Programming] --> B[Primal Problem]
    A --> C[Dual Problem]
    B --> B1[Objective Function]
    B --> B2[Constraints]
    B --> B3[Decision Variables]

    D[DEA] --> D1[Efficiency Score]
    D --> D2[Reference Units]
    D --> D3[LP Formulation]
```

#### **Graph 4: Conjoint Analysis**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Conjoint Analysis] --> B[Part-Worth Utilities]
    A --> C[Approaches]
    C --> C1[Regression]
    C --> C2[Optimization]
    A --> D[Ideal Product]
    D --> D1[Distance Minimization]
```

---
### **Key Equations Summary**
| **Topic**               | **Equation**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Conditional Probability | \( P(A|B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} \)                                    |
| Linear Regression       | \( Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \dots + \beta_n X_n \)                     |
| R-squared               | \( R^2 = 1 - \frac{SS_{res}}{SS_{tot}} \)                                  |
| Adjusted R-squared      | \( 1 - \frac{(1-R^2)(n-1)}{n-p-1} \)                                       |
| VIF                     | \( VIF_i = \frac{1}{1 - R_i^2} \)                                          |
| Chi-Square Statistic    | \( \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_i - E_i)^2}{E_i} \)                              |
| Logistic Regression     | \( \log \left( \frac{p}{1-p} \right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \dots \)   |
| Accuracy                | \( \frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN} \)                                    |
| Recall                  | \( \frac{TP}{TP + FN} \)                                                   |
| Precision               | \( \frac{TP}{TP + FP} \)                                                   |
| LP Objective            | Maximize/Minimize \( c^T x \)                                              |
| DEA Efficiency          | \( \theta = \frac{\sum u_i y_i}{\sum v_j x_j} \)                          |
